case_name: K.C. Nayar v. Chairman, Central Tractor Organisation

facts.text: Petition No. 107 of 1957 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 107 of 1957. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental. Rights.

facts.text: Petition prays for writ of mandamus or other writ to respondents to remove ban against petitioner's entry into government service.

anchor.surface_text: Th-is petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution prays for a writ of mandamus or any other appropriate writ or direction to the respondents to remove the- ban. against the petitioner against his entry into government service.

facts.text: Respondents are Chairman, Central Tractor Organisation; Secretary, Ministry of Food and Agriculture; Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents to the petition are The Chairman, Central Tractor Organisation, Ministry of Food and Agriculture, Government of-India, New Delhi. The Secretary, Ministry of Food and Agriculture, NewDelhi. The Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, New Delhi.

facts.text: Petitioner is a trained machineman.

anchor.surface_text: The petition is founded on the following allegations. The petitioner is a trained machineman.

facts.text: Petitioner employed as machineman in Central Tractor Organisation in 1948.

anchor.surface_text: In 1948, he was employed as a machineman in the Central Tractor Organisation.

facts.text: Petitioner continued in government service until services terminated by notice dated September 16, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: He companytinued in government service and rendered a good account of himself in that service until, by a numberice dated September 16, 1954, his services were terminated.

facts.text: Termination order No. 375 dated September 16, 1954 stated services no longer required, terminated with immediate effect, one month pay in lieu under Rule 5 of Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The office order No. 375 terminating his services is at Annexure A to the petition and is in these terms Shri K. C. Nayar s o Dr. Tara Chand Designation M Man is informed that his services are numberlonger required in this Organisation. His services will accordingly stand terminated with immediate effect from the date on which this numberice is served on him. In lieu of the numberice for one month due to him under rule 5 of the Central Civil Service  Temporary Service  Rules, Shri K.C. Nayar will be given pay and allowances, for that period.

facts.text: Petitioner's appeal against termination order rejected on December 6, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner appealed against the said order of termination of his services, but his, appeal was rejected. on December 6, 1954  Annexure B .

facts.text: Petitioner obtained service certificate stating served from 13-5-1948 to 21-9-1954 as Machineman, terminated under Rule 5 of Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the petitioner applied for and obtained p, certificate-in the following terms  Annexure Certified that Shri Krishan Chancier Nayar served in this organisation as a Machineman in the scale of Rs. 125-6-185 with effect from 13-5-1948 to 21-9-1954. His services were terminated under Rule 5 of the Central Civil Services  Temporary Service  Rules, 1949.

facts.text: Petitioner made several applications for government appointment but without success.

anchor.surface_text: After receiving the certificate aforesaid, the petitioner made several applications for appointment under the Government, but without any results.

facts.text: Respondents placed a ban on petitioner being taken into government service, as per memorandum refusing to lift ban in response to representations dated September 9, 1955 and September 21, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Later on the petitioner learnt to his dismay that the respondents had placed a ban on the petitioner being ever taken into government service. The alleged ban is companytained in the following memorandum  Annexure D  With reference to his representations dated September 9, 1955 and September 21,1955, the undersigned is directed to inform Shri K.C. Nayar, Ex-Mac hineman that Government of India regret their inability to lift the ban on his employment for the present.

facts.text: Petitioner filed petition under Article 226 in Circuit Bench of Delhi of Punjab High Court, dismissed in limine on September 12, 1956; application for certificate for appeal dismissed on April 26, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It is this ban which, the petitioner pleads, has discriminated against him in the matter of government employment. The petitioner moved the Circuit Bench of Delhi of the High Court of Judicature for the State of Punjab, under Art. 226 of the Constitution, but his petition was dismissed ,in limine by the Division Bench of that Court by its order dated September 12, 1956, and an application for grant of the, necessary certificate for ,appealing to this Court was also dismissed by the Bench on April 26., 1957.

facts.text: Supreme Court petition under Article 32 filed on August 20, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: This Court was moved under Art. 32 of the Constitution by a petition dated August 20, 1957.

facts.text: Central Tractor Organisation is a temporary organisation under Ministry of Agriculture, Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: the affidavit aforesaid on behalf of the respondents states that the Central Tractor Organisation is a temporary organisation under the Ministry of Agriculture, Government of India

facts.text: Petitioner appointed as purely temporary hand, services liable to termination at any time by one month's notice or pay in lieu without reasons.

anchor.surface_text: that the petitioner was appointed as a purely temporary hand and that his services were liable to termination at any time by giving him one months numberice or one months pay in lieu of th- numberice and without assigning any reasons.

facts.text: Petitioner's services terminated in accordance with Rule 5 of Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The statement is repeated more than once that the petitioners services were duly terminated in accordance with r. 5 of the Central Civil Services  Temporary Service  Rules, 1949.

facts.text: Respondents deny putting a ban that deprives petitioner of right to apply for government service; state applications would be considered on merits.

anchor.surface_text: Referring to paragraphs 6 7 of the petition I do number admit that the Respondents had put a ban on the petitioner being taken into Government service I say that the, petitioner was number deprived of his right to apply for any service, and that the petitioner had numberright to appointment. to a Government Service But it is submitted that the peti- tioner is entitled to apply for any. government service and such application would be companysidered on its merits.

facts.text: Alleged ban was departmental instruction for future guidance, does not prevent applying for posts, applications entertained on merits.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the ban alleged by the petitioner it is submitted that it was purely a Departmental instruction for future guidance which did or does number in any way prevent the petitioner from applying for any post under the Govt. and such application of the peti- tioner will be entertained on merits and the petitioner is number debarred from applying for any post under the Government as he has alleged in his petition.

facts.text: No show cause notice required as governed by Rule 5 of Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: As the petitioner was governed by Rule 5 of the Central Civil Services  Temporary Service  Rules, 1949, numberquestion of the issue of any show cause numberice can arise.

facts.text: Government considered petitioner's representation for reinstatement, took into account circumstances and antecedents, found not desirable to reinstate.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the question of ban is companycerned it is further submitted that after the petitioner had submitted his repre- sentation to the Chairman, Central Trator Organisation, for reinstatement it was duly companysidered by the Government which took into companysideration all the circumstances and the antecedents of the, petitioner and came to the finding that it would number be desirable to re- instate him.

facts.text: Respondent affidavit incorrectly states that petitioner's special leave petition from Punjab High Court was dismissed by Supreme Court on April 26, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Referring to paragraph 11 of the petition it is submitted that the petitioner is number entitled to move this Honble Court under Article 32 of the Constitution after his application for special leave before this Honble Court from the judgment of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench, was dismissed on the 26th of April, 1957, and the order passed by this Honble Court dismissing the said special leave petition on, the 26th of April, 1957 is final between the parties and should be treated as res judicata against the present applications.

facts.text: No special leave application was filed in Supreme Court; High Court refused certificate for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact, there was numbersuch special leave application filed in this Court, and, therefore, there is numberfoundation, in fact, for that averment. What appears to have happened is that the High Court refused to grant the necessary certificate when it was moved to certify that was a fit case for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: There is a ban on petitioner's employment under government; it prevents consideration of his applications on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of the denial on behalf of the respondents that there was numberban against the petitioners employment under the Government, the fact of the matter is that the petitioner is under a ban in the matter of employment under the, Government, and that so long as the ban companytinues, he cannot be companysidered by any Government department for any post for which he may make ail application, and for which he may be found qualified.

facts.text: Petitioner deprived of constitutional right of equality of opportunity in employment under Article 16(1).

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, therefore, that the petitioner has been deprived of his companystitutional right of equality of opportunity in matters of employment or appointment to any office under the State, companytained in Art. 16 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: No proceeding taken against petitioner giving opportunity to show cause against the ban.

anchor.surface_text: whatever may have been the nature of the ban, there does number appear to have been any proceeding taken against the petitioner giving him the opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed to be taken against him.

facts.text: Court directs respondents to remove the ban against the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The application is, therefore, allowed and a direction issued to the respondents to remove the ban against the petitioner.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 23, 1961 by Sinha C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. August 23.The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA C. J.-

holdings.text: There was no special leave application filed in this Court from the High Court judgment, and thus no dismissal thereof operating as res judicata barring the Article 32 petition.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact, there was numbersuch special leave application filed in this Court, and, therefore, there is numberfoundation, in fact, for that averment. What appears to have happened is that the High Court refused to grant the necessary certificate when it was moved to certify that was a fit case for appeal to this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court corrects factual error in respondent's affidavit; no SLP filed, only High Court certificate refused.

holdings.text: Despite respondents' denial, the petitioner is under a ban on employment under the Government which prevents consideration of his applications on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of the denial on behalf of the respondents that there was numberban against the petitioners employment under the Government, the fact of the matter is that the petitioner is under a ban in the matter of employment under the, Government, and that so long as the ban companytinues, he cannot be companysidered by any Government department for any post for which he may make ail application, and for which he may be found qualified.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Memorandum (Annexure D) evidences ban; denial contradicted by effect preventing merit consideration.

holdings.text: The ban, imposed without disclosing its nature, justification, or giving opportunity to show cause, deprives the petitioner of equality of opportunity under Article 16(1).

anchor.surface_text: If the affidavit on behalf of the respondents had clearly indicated the nature of the ban and the justification therefore, the Court would have been in a better position in deciding the question whether or number the petitioner had any substantial grounds for companyplaining against the treatment, meted out to, him. A person whohas once

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit fails to justify ban; no hearing provided, rendering it arbitrary and unrelated to suitability.

holdings.text: An arbitrary ban without reasonable basis or relation to suitability amounts to denial of equal opportunity under Article 16(1).

anchor.surface_text: guaranteed under Art. 16 1  of the Constitntion. In the instant case, the affidavit filed on behalf of the respondents does number indicate the nature of the ban, and whatever may have been the nature of the ban, there does number appear to have been any proceeding taken against the petitioner giving him the opportunity of showing cause against the action proposed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ban must relate to suitability; arbitrariness violates constitutional guarantee without due process.

holdings.text: Article 16(1) guarantees not only the right to apply for government employment but also the right to be considered on merits.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation of equality of opportunity requires merit-based consideration, not mere application.

holdings.text: The petitioner has been deprived of his constitutional right under Article 16(1), and the respondents are directed to remove the ban.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, therefore, that the petitioner has been deprived of his companystitutional right of equality of opportunity in matters of employment or appointment to any office under the State, companytained in Art. 16 1  of the Constitution. ... The application is, therefore, allowed and a direction issued to the respondents to remove the ban against the petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of ban's arbitrariness and violation of consideration right warrants mandamus remedy.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact, there was numbersuch special leave application filed in this Court, and, therefore, there is numberfoundation, in fact, for that averment. What appears to have happened is that the High Court refused to grant the necessary certificate when it was moved to certify that was a fit case for appeal to this Court.
The application is, therefore, allowed and a direction issued to the respondents to remove the ban against the petitioner.

In spite of the denial on behalf of the respondents that there was numberban against the petitioners employment under the Government, the fact of the matter is that the petitioner is under a ban in the matter of employment under the, Government, and that so long as the ban companytinues, he cannot be companysidered by any Government department for any post for which he may make ail application, and for which he may be found qualified.
The application is, therefore, allowed and a direction issued to the respondents to remove the ban against the petitioner.
